text: why is it that some plugs have two
prongs but others have three it's all
about safety electricity must flow in an
uninterrupted circuit take a look at
your home outlets for instance the right
smaller slot is for the hot wire this is
where the electricity comes from the
left wider slot is for the neutral wire
this wire completes the circuit and
feeds electricity back into the system
but implement this idea into a larger
power distribution system and you've
created a huge problem if excess voltage
is applied to the circuit like lightning
strain all of the excess energy must
travel through your electrical network
potentially exploding everything
connected to it to prevent this 1/3
ground wire is connected from your
breaker box and is driven straight into
the earth now on that same lightning
strikes your system the excess energy is
directed into the land instead but we've
now created another problem before all
of this the only way to be shocked was
if you touched both the neutral and hot
wires in that case your body would close
the electrical circuit and the voltage
would travel through you from one wire
to the other but now because of
grounding half of the electrical system
is always indirectly connected to you
through your feet meaning you only need
to touch a single wire or a metal object
electrified by one to become an
unfortunate circuit this is why some
appliances have the third prong it's a
safety feature for devices with metal
cases through wear and tear aging or
faulty manufacturing a hot wire from
within the appliance could come loose
and make contact with the metallic case
without this prong you could be lethally
shocked when touching it but appliances
with this third prong have a wire that
connects directly from the metallic case
and back to the outlet voltage along
this path will trip the breaker box and
cut off all electricity that could have
killed you so the next time you see that
large third prong just know that it
could have already saved your life
you
